title: 2012 FSR-Jason's Deli Annual NC CX Cross Race
course: This is the same great course as last Januaryâ€™s Double-Points race, with a combination of pavement, grass, clay track, sand, if it rains-mud! This is a very spectator-friendly course and beginners are highly encouraged to come out and give it a try.
registration: On line registration through www.Pre-Reg.com, Race Day Registrationopens at 9:00 am and closes 30 minutes before the start of each event. USA Cycling racing licenses or One Day USA Cycling licenses are required to cover liability and medical insurance; One Day Licenses will be available on site for $10. This is a competitive event officially permitted by FSR and USA Cycling (pending). All entrants are required to sign the USCF Standard Athletes Release Form. Minors must have a parent or guardian with them when registering to sign the release form. Sorry, no mail in registration.
directions:

title: East Blvd Bar & Grill Winter Short Track Mountain

Carolinas Pain Institute Road Race Weekend
description: A two-day event through the rolling hills of East Bend and a park crit located at the Dixie Classic Fair
course: The RR on Saturday is a 10.72 mile loop in East Bend, NC. Course will be raced in a clockwise fashion. It is fast with two short climbs. The Crit on Sunday is a .81 mile loop with a small rise to the finish line. The course is featured next to BB&T Stadium.
registration: Collegiate Registration will be done on acccycling.org. Public Registration will be done on pre-reg.com
notes: All races will follow the NCCA, ACCC and USAC rules. Annual licenses are required for all categories except for collegiate C, D, WB and WC. Riders without an annual license must purchase a one day license for $10. Races will be wheel in, wheel out. Approved helmets are required at all times when riding a bike. Race held rain or shine. Promoter reserves the right to combine categories.
directions:
Saturday: From Raleigh/Greensboro: 1-40W to US-421N. Take Exit 244 towards Lewisville. At the traffic circle, take 1st exit onto Williams Rd. Left at Shallowford Rd. Right at Conrad Rd. Left at Yadkinville Rd. Right at Flint Hill Rd. Flint Hill Vineyards is on the left - 2133 Flint Hill Road, East Bend, NC. 

Sunday: 411 Deacon Boluevard, Winston-Salem, NC.

title: Lees-McRae Junior Road Camp
description: Junior Development Camp with spectacular roads, LMC coaches and riders investing to help riders improve, guest speakers, and more.  For Ages 15-18 years old Male riders only
course: Roads can be very challenging.  A 39x 27 is the recommended minimum. A compact crank is preferred.  Due to mountain weather, pack for all conditions. Good tires with spare tubes, pumps, and several changes of cloths will be needed.
registration: Register online at www.lmc.edu on the athletics page.
notes: Camp will include clinics on climbing, sprinting, training, bike handling, etc.  This camp will allow riders to get as much out of it as they want.  There is nothing to lose and all to gain.

title: Ridge Rollers Spring Training Ride
description: Ridge Rollers Velo Spring Training Ride
course: Local route in Mt. Airy.  Leaves Grace Moravian Church and ascends Orchard Gap.
notes: Out and back with no prices

title: Powerade State Games of NC Mountain Bike Race
Camp CycleYouth
description:
MTB summer camp for ages 12-18.
Sport camp June 10-16.
Expert Camp June 17-23.
The Expert Camp is set up more as a training camp where riders will do a lot of riding and training during the week, this is also open to Sport level riders who should be racing Ex.  Attendees prefer this format rather than our previous usacycling format of classroom heavy learning.  The fitness gains from this week of training will carry you to new levels.

There will be qualifications to attend the Ex camp.  We will use mostly race results to qualify campers.  The reason is to ensure a group that is similar in fitness which will help maintain economy during the rides. If you are racing Sport (Cat II) or Junior Sport or Expert in 2012 then you are most of the way there.  If you are racing the Beginner (Base) class then you likely will not have the fitness/endurance/speed that theExpert racers have, so consider the Beginner/Sport Camp.

Expert (cay 1) rides are typically 2-3 hours per day with the 6-day total being around 12-14 hours at minimum.  This is a training camp, so expect a little suffering and sore legs.  Participants should be highly motivated and ready to go each day. This will be more boot-camp than previous camps.

The Beginner/Sport Camp is open to anyone with the ability and motivation to ride 6 consecutive days at 1.5-2 hours per, with a long ride extending past 3 hours possibly.

These are camps put on by CycleYouth staff, but are open to any racer or mtb\'er on any team able to ride with the group.  Most Sport/Ex campers are very fast Sport level racers. over age 16  Rides will range from 2 to 3 hours long, and some days will have two-a-dayers where we ride in the morning and also the afternoon.  On the long days we will offer shorter options for any not feeling up to the task, and may opt for a longer ride depending on the group.   The area\'s Forest are a beautiful riding location nestled in the Blue ridge mountains. The area is hilly and mountainous, so we will be riding rolling terrain one day and mountainous the next.  Early morning activities include strength and conditioning training and other off-bike training related interest.

The Beginner/Sport camp  includes racers of this ability level, and some non-racers who have the fitness and endurance to complete the rides with the group.  This is not a camp for those interested in beginning mountain bike, however.  The fitness needed to complete the rides can only come from riding a bike (not running, swimming, or other sports).  Generally those who do well are riders who currently ride 3-4 days per week for 1-2 hours on each ride. One-day-a-week riders will not be able to keep up with the group.  General fitness, proficiencies in other sports, motivation and determination are of no help for a non-cyclist or a cyclist that rarely rides.

The camps intent is to help cyclist jump to the next level both in fitness and in skills.  Many other areas of discussion will be covered to help create a well-rounded cyclist.
Skills are hands on at the cabin or on the trails while instruction is a laid-back conversation style.  For those interested we will offer a more structured discussion on training.  We will skip the science and go directly to what matters in training.   We will cover skills as in the past but more emphasis will be on training.

We will discuss proper bike care and go over basic bike maintain and repair during optional instruction time.  Riders will learn the basics of the training method and begin to understand the intricacies of race preparation, execution, nutrition and how training works.  Campers will enjoy the good life with excellent trails and rides led by local residents and other camp staff.  

This camp was formerly part of the USA Cycling camp system, but has removed itself from this format.  This camp will be the same successful format developed for that camp, just with more appropriate goals.  This camp can still serve as a qualifier for the USAC camp.

Food and lodging included.  Campers only need towels and [some will need] linens for bedding (or sleeping bag).  Early arrival, and transportation from Atlanta can be arranged.  Airport pickup can also be arranged fom Greenville/Spartanberg or Asheville Int.
registration:
NC Camp Cost $550 for one week.
Includes meals, lodging and transportation during the camp.
This is a USAC sanctioned event so campers will need a USAC license to attend (available to purchase upon arrival). www.usacycling.org 
Space is limited to 12 participants maximum at each one-week camp!
See CycleYouth.com for registration info.  Paypal or Check.
Please check with camp staff for qualifications.
notes: Camp starts 8am Monday morning, but arrival on Sunday is preferred.  Campers will have option to do a short ride Sunday evening.
directions: Since this even involves minors directions will be given to registrants only.  The area is Cedar Mountain, NC.

title: Ride to the Rock
description:
The Ride to the Rock at Chimney Rock 25 Mile Bike ride is part of the \"3 RACES IN 3 DAYS\" challenge. You can choose to do this one event only or if you are brave enough take part in all 3 races. Can you handle it? If you think you can, you must start out with the Lake Lure 10K Dam Run on Friday night. Saturday morning the Lake Lure Triathlon will test your swim, bike, and run skills. Then to top it off, Sunday is this event, the Ride to the Rock.....either the 25 Mile Bike or the 5K Run (click HERE for the run).....you choose.

The 25 Mile Bike begins at 7:30 AM just outside the park entrance. This is a beautiful yet challenging bike course. It is 22 miles until you reach the park entrance as the last 3 miles moves straight up Chimney Rock State Park. All cyclists must be inside the park gates by 9:30 AM. If you do not reach the park entrance by 9:30 AM a race organizer will meet you at the front gate to remove your timing chip.
course:
Course Maps can be found here:
http://setupevents.com/files/BIKEMAP_RACETOROCK.pdf
registration:
You can register by visiting the following link:
http://setupevents.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=event_detail&eventID=2097

Registration cost: $40.00
Packet Pickup - Sunday August 26 6-7 AM at Old Rock Cafe - 431 Main St, Chimney Rock, NC
directions: Address is 431 Main St, Chimney Rock, NC

title: Abby Construction Cyclocross Series
description: Tuesday Nights, Under the Lights returns to Boone thanks to the generous support of Abby Construction!
course: Fun, spectator friendly, twisty, flat and short, with one hard run-up.
registration: Sign up on site for $15. Kids only $5

title: Town Mountain Hill Climb Time Trial
Appalachian State Mountain Bike Race Weekend
description: Appalachian State University races will be held in Boone\'s own Rocky Knob Mountain bike park only 3 miles from campus. Saturday\'s events will consist of a challenging uphill time trial, Short Track event that promises for some excitement and a short climb, and finishing with Super D using the famous PBJ jump line. Super D will be TT format. Sunday will be also at Rocky Knob and be a challenging Cross Country course will challenging climbs, and super fast downhills. Be mindful that parking is limited try and carpool if possible.
course: Uphill time trial will use Rocky Branch trail, and the Climb of Middle Earth with technical rocky terrain. Short track will start and finish at the saddle and use a brief portion of the power line climb which will lead riders through the upper mini skills park, and then drop down top section of PBJ, dropping riders back onto the power line. Short, Fast, and spectator friendly short track! Super D will use the famous PBJ jump line full of big berms, rock gardens, jumps, pumps and rollers. Sundays Cross Country course will start and finish in the parking lot. Riders will begin ascending right from the gun. Climbing up Rocky Branch Trail, the first Middle Earth, Boat Rock, (A riders will then turn off onto \'Ol Hoss - a super technical descent), all riders will then be on the downhill back to start finish.
registration: Registration for event is at  http://acccycling.org/Registration.html
directions:
Rocky Knob Park is located on US 421 just east of Boone city limits. From downtown, take US 421 S towards Wilkesboro. The park is located just off 421 on the right 7/10 of a mile past Bamboo Road and the Marathon Gas Station
Entrance Coordinates: 36.223287,-81.62654

title: Wilkesboro Cyclocross Festival
description: Two Days of Bikes, Cowbells, and Beer at the Third Annual Wilkesboro Cyclocross Festival. Day Two is also race #5 in the North Carolina Cyclo-Cross Series. Brought to you by the Wilkesboro Tourism Development Agency - please choose to spend the night in Wilkes County.
course: Euro-Style Awesomeness! Extreme Vertical! Real Bathrooms! Hot Showers! Go to www.HighCountryCX.com/course for a detailed venue map and a windshield tour video
registration: Online registration at www.Pre-Reg.com through night before each race - $10 extra if you wait until race day.
notes:

For detailed information about NCCX go to www.nccyclocross.com
Only Sunday Races count toward NCCX standings
*MTB is not a NCCX category
